Meaning IN CONTEXT: (vinaya) elder; senior monk; monk with ten or more years as a monk; lit. lasting
Commentary:
(VINa) thero vā'ti ādīsu vayovuḍḍh'ādīsu yo vā so vā hotu, paripuṇṇadasavassatāya thero vā ūnapañcavassatāya navo vā atirekapañcavassatāya majjhimo vā'ti attho.
(SNa) navo'ti aparipuṇṇapañcavasso hi bhikkhu navo nāma hoti, pañcavassato paṭṭhāya majjhimo, dasavassato paṭṭhāya thero.
Example1:
na tena thero so hoti, yen'assa palitaṃ siro,
paripakko vayo tassa, moghajiṇṇo'ti vuccati.
Example2: tassa me therassa sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ
eng-old: elder; senior monk; monk with 10 or more vassa; lit. lasting

Meaning IN CONTEXT: Such Become; Realised; being in such a state; arrived at the truth; epithet of the Buddha
Notes: Bhikkhu Sujāta: the EBTs give a fairly extensive set of interpretations for tathāgata, for example, "as he says, so he does". The overall sense is of one who speaks and acts in accordance with his realization of the truth, which fits the translation "the Realized One".

Example2: so taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati. so tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati

Meaning IN CONTEXT: neutral; neither unpleasant nor pleasant; neither comfortable nor uncomfortable
Commentary: (VINa) adukkham'asukhan'ti dukkh'ābhāvena adukkhaṃ, sukh'ābhāvena asukhaṃ. eten'ettha dukkhasukhapaṭipakkhabhūtaṃ tatiyavedanaṃ dīpeti, na dukkhasukhābhāvamattaṃ. tatiyavedanā nāma, adukkhamasukhā, upekkhā'ti'pi vuccati. sā iṭṭh'āniṭṭhaviparīt'ānubhavanalakkhaṇā, majjhattarasā, avibhūtapaccupaṭṭhānā, sukhanirodhapadaṭṭhānā'ti veditabbā.
Example1: sukham'pi vedayati, dukkham'pi vedayati, adukkham'asukham'pi vedayati. vedayatī'ti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā vedanā'ti vuccati.
Example3: n'eva tasmiṃ samaye dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, na adukkham'asukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti
Example4: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubb'eva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅ'gamā, adukkham'asukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
eng-old: neutral; neither pleasant nor unpleasant; neither comfortable nor uncomfortable
Feedback: Spot a mistake? Fix it here.

Meaning IN CONTEXT: (vinaya) defeated; deposed; disqualified; expelled; lit. who has been conquered
Commentary:
(VIN 6.8.5) pārājikan'ti yaṃ vuttaṃ,
taṃ suṇohi yathātathaṃ,
cuto paraddho bhaṭṭho ca,
saddhammā hi niraṅkato,
saṃvāso'pi tahiṃ n'atthi,
ten'etaṃ iti vuccati.
(VINa) pārājiko'ti parājito, parājayaṃ āpanno.
Notes: Indic Languages in Brill's Encyclopedia of Buddhism: "Similarly, the correct derivation and original meaning of the legal technical term pārājika based on the Vedic verb parā + aj-, "to drive away," probably originally belonging to the vocabulary of cattle keepers and therefore unknown to the Buddhist tradition, which sought a connection to parā + ji-, "to defeat" (pārājika > pārājayika), were found out by one of the pioneers of Western Buddhist studies, E. Burnouf, as early as 1844 and confirmed again by H. Smith in 1966 (von Hinüber, 1988, 3)"

Meaning IN CONTEXT: mental liberation; emancipation of heart; (comm) samadhi obtained from fruition
Commentary:
(ANa) rāgavirāgā cetovimuttī'ti rāgassa khayavirāgena cetovimutti nāma hoti. phalasamādhiss'etaṃ nāmaṃ.
(DNa) akuppā cetovimuttī'ti arahattaphalavimutti.
Example1: mettāya cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ekādas'ānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
Example2: seyyathā'pi balavā saṅkhadhamo appakasiren'eva catuddisā viññāpeyya, evam'eva kho evaṃ bhāvitāya mettāya cetovimuttiyā yaṃ pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ na taṃ tatrāvasissati, na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhati.
Example3: dve kho, āvuso, paccayā animittāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā, sabbanimittānañ'ca amanasikāro, animittāya ca dhātuyā manasikāro.

Notes: (BDN) they are unshakable by their opposites: (1) the power of faith is unshakable by faithlessness (unbelief); (2) energy, by laziness; (3) mindfulness, by forgetfulness; (4) concentration, by distractedness; (5) wisdom, by ignorance. They represent, therefore, the aspect of firmness in the spiritual faculties.
Example3: seyyath'īdaṃ, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā cattāro iddhipādā pañc'indriyāni pañca balāni satta bojjh'aṅgā ariyo aṭṭh'aṅgiko maggo.

Commentary:
(SNa) samāhito'ti upacārena vā appanāya vā samāhito.
(ANa) samāhitassā'ti ekaggacittassa.
(THa) samāhitan'ti aṭṭhavidhena samādhinā maggaphalasamādhinā ca samāhitaṃ.

Meaning IN CONTEXT: remembered; retained in mind; known off by heart
Commentary: (ANa) dhātā'ti dhātā paguṇā. ekaccassa hi uggahitabuddhavacanaṃ dhātaṃ paguṇaṃ niccalikaṃ na hoti, asukaṃ suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā kathehī'ti vutte, sajjhāyitvā saṃsanditvā samanuggāhitvā jānissāmī'ti vadati. ekaccassa dhātaṃ paguṇaṃ bhav'aṅgasotasadisaṃ hoti, asukaṃ suttaṃ vā jātakaṃ vā kathehī'ti vutte uddharitvā tam'eva katheti. taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ dhātā'ti.
Example1: idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo khippanisantī ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu, sutānañ'ca dhammānaṃ dhārakajātiko hoti, dhātānañ'ca dhammānaṃ atth'ūpaparikkhī hoti attham'aññāya dhammam'aññāya, dhamm'ānudhammappaṭipanno hoti.
Example2: tathārūpā'ssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manas'ānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā. idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sutadhanaṃ
Example3: tathārūpā'ssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manas'ānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā. idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sutadhanaṃ

Meaning IN CONTEXT: well learned; knowledgeable; lit. much heard
Commentary:
(SNa) bahussutassā'ti pariyattibahussutassa paṭivedhabahussutassa ca.
(ANa) bahussuto hotī'ti bahuṃ assa sutaṃ hoti, nav'aṅgaṃ satthusāsanaṃ pāḷianusandhipubb'āparavasena uggahitaṃ hotī'ti attho.
Example1: bahussuto nu kho'mhi sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti.
Example2: asukasmiṃ nāma āvāse sambahulā therā bhikkhū viharanti bahussutā āgat'āgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā. tesaṃ me therānaṃ sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ
Example3: tathārūpā'ssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manas'ānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā. idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sutadhanaṃ

anānupuṭṭho'va paresa pāva,
anariyadhammaṃ kusalā tam'āhu,
yo ātumānaṃ sayam'eva pāva.

Example2:

Example1: tassa sā sukhā vedanā nirujjhati. sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. so dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
Example3:

khaṇ'ātītā hi socanti, nirayamhi samappitā.

Example3: yaṃ kho tumhe, āyasmanto, bhikkhuṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ pahiṇittha na taṃ tassa bhikkhuno kiñci atthaṃ anubhoti: yuñjant'āyasmanto sakaṃ, mā vo sakaṃ vinassā'ti.

(MNa) catumaggañāṇasaṅkhātehi vedehi akusaladhammānaṃ gatattā vedagū hoti, viditattā'ti attho.
(THa) vedagū'ti vedena gato maggañāṇena nibbānaṃ gato adhigato, cattāri vā saccāni pariññā-pahāna-sacchikiriyā-bhāvan'ābhisamayavasena abhisamecca ṭhito.
(SNa) jātu vedagū'ti ahaṃ ek'aṃsen'eva vedagū, vedasaṅkhātena ñāṇena neyyesu gato, vedaṃ vā gato adhigato, paṇḍito'ham'asmī'ti attho.
Example1: kathañ'ca bhikkhu vedagū hoti? vidit'āssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṃkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṃ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā
Example2:
sa ve samm'addaso bhikkhu, parijānāti vedanā.
so vedanā pariññāya, diṭṭhe dhamme anāsavo.
kāyassa bhedā dhammaṭṭho, saṅkhyaṃ n'opeti vedagū'ti.
eng-old: who has perfect knowledge; complete understanding; lit. gone through the Vedas
